body: @elloooooo If you save it as parquet, I think there will be no problem of `HiveDecimal` any more.
Parquet does support [decimal](https://github.com/apache/parquet-format/blob/master/LogicalTypes.md#decimal), but it sounds like @elloooooo is talking about ORC, not Parquet.

Your observation is correct the console does not show information about the task location after it is done. Currently the information like start time, task location is not saved when the task is done. Only task id, status, duration and task payload are saved. 

As far as I know, I think the reason being when middle manager nodes were introduced the idea was they are considered ephemeral in the sense new MMs can be spawned on demand and when not required they can be taken down. Thus, it does not help much to save task location information.

However, you can still access the logs from the console, you will need to send them to deep storage so that they can be streamed from there on demand. See `Task Logging` section here - http://druid.io/docs/latest/configuration/indexing-service.html
If you have non empty `metricsSpec` in the Supervisor specification then this shouldn't be printed.
If I'm reading this correctly it will cause a bunch of double-logging to both the request logger and the application logs on query cancellation / query interrupted (on purpose).
See also https://groups.google.com/d/msg/druid-user/V6CqunkE5Qs/SSC8-dc6DQAJ.
Would anyone please review this patch?
Taking a look.
I assume this was a test of some kind, so I'm closing the PR. Welcome @DanielChou1990 though :)

In the Google Group @gianm correctly said I can add 
"jobProperties" : {
  "mapreduce.map.java.opts" : "-server -Xms512m -Xmx512m -Ddruid.javascript.enabled=true -Duser.timezone=UTC -Dfile.encoding=UTF-8",
  "mapreduce.reduce.java.opts" : "-server -Xms2g -Xmx2g -Ddruid.javascript.enabled=true -Duser.timezone=UTC -Dfile.encoding=UTF-8"
}

to the jobProperties to set the system properties on the job, making it enable javascript.

Its probably worth either documenting this or adding code to have the Indexing Service pass this down to the Hadoop job.

Actually not using the SDK raises many issues. Especially It is a best practice to not use credentials whenever possible and using roles / instance profiles instead.
This is impossible with the current implementation.
What about also updating jetty version to `9.3.18.v20170406`?
You can use instance profiles. The credential chain is here https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/aws-common/src/main/java/io/druid/common/aws/AWSCredentialsUtils.java
@leventov it was not required to pull in the classes. So I'd rather do it in another PR unless you know of specific issues with the http/2 servelet in masters current version

@drcrallen no, this is catching and logging the exception, metrics etc in the anonymous class implementation which are not currently (before #4169 ) caught or logged. For example try sending a query using `curl -m 1 ...` that takes a few seconds , curl will close connection on its side in a sec and druid request log  or metrics would have no trace of this query if response writing failed.
thank you. that wasn't quite clear from the docs

@b-slim cool, also take a look at #4180 - it might be a good idea to see if we can pass down the majority of the druid.* properties into the map and reduce JVMs to mitigate this class of issues - I was playing around with this earlier and ran into problems when I just blanket passed them all in (I think it was related to the extensions loadList probably due to the way we handle extensions in MR jobs) but I didn't investigate any further
Related to https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/1415
duplicate of #1415

GroupByMergingQueryRunnerV2 has two things that could time out: merge buffer acquisition in the request thread, and processing in the processing threads. It handles that by computing a `timeoutAt` value (absolute time) and using that to calculate all future timeouts.

I guess we could extend this to the broker, and have `timeoutAt` be something that gets set very early in query processing and respected throughout the stack.

copied from #4181 

if all historicals (and peon) respond within the query timeout specified and it is broker spending time doing the merge (usually in the case of merging lots of sketches) then timeout wouldn't be honored irrespective of however long broker takes to merge things.

on the client side, clients typically use the same timeout to close the connection... so broker doing all the work is eventually wasted.

i think its most problematic with query types that don't do streaming merge at broker.

one possibly simple (maybe crude) fix is that broker puts query processing `startTime` in query context and all things taking time to process the query continuously watch the time spent and fail if it exceeds. I'm imagining probably in QueryToolChest.mergeResults(..) impl and may be in the QueryResource where it is streaming the results to response.

another alternative to `startTime` would be to do query processing in a thread pool and cancel the future on query timeout .... druid code that takes time in processing the query would continuously check if the thread is interrupted.
https://github.com/druid-io/druid/releases/tag/druid-0.10.0

@gianm `timeoutAt` sounds similar to setting the `startTime` ,  either sound good to me.
on broker, i believe there are only two places where most of the time is spent ... either in MergeSequence created by CachingClusteredClient or QueryToolChest.mergeResults(..) impls
Will take a final look tomorrow.

Looks probably related to the large column code path from #3743. @akashdw, @cheddar, any ideas?

@arpankhagram, the large column code path should only get activated if a single column is >2GB. In this case it looks like it's a file for one of your string columns. You might be able to work around this by lowering maxRowsPerSegment in your tuningConfig.

Fwiw, in 0.9.2 trying to write a large string column would have failed too, with a different error: columns >2GB weren't supported at all. I'm surprised you only saw this after upgrading. Maybe something else happened to trigger a really large column getting generated. Perhaps just having the system stopped for a while led to a data backlog that led to large segments.

At any rate -- I'd suggest try lowering maxRowsPerSegment and see if that helps.
@gianm  @himanshug  After yesterday's dev sync, I created #4184 and removed query.queryMetrics property, as part of this PR. Only bug fixing / refactoring part of this PR is remaining.

We were using 0.10-snapahot (taken on 23rd March) until now and it looks to have broke after Kafka upgrade to 0.10.2.0.

Yes we are having very large columns - anyways I shall try with lowering maxRowsPerSegment and let you know if that works fine.

Looks nobody have received this error earlier - I tried searching in forums.

Thanks.

@pjain1 So is it possible to display location and start/end time on UI as per current code architecture ?
It will probably fail since it's been timed out. Tasks are only allowed a certain amount of time to restore after disappearing before the overlord gives up.

I found the port used was 8091 , it's in conf file for middleManager , I changed it to 8092 and service started fine .

-Rahul

@drcrallen, I'm not very familiar with either HTTP/2 or Jetty's implementation of it. So I'm wondering:

- Is HTTP/2 going to be optional or always on with this patch?
- Is it on the same port as HTTP 1? Or a different port?
- Have you tested running servers with this patch?
- Any risks you can think of for committing this?

Two other questions:

- Will HTTP/2 be used internally for Druid by anything after this patch (is there any sort of auto detection on the http-client side)? I think the answer is no, and that http-client doesn't support HTTP/2 anyway, but just confirming.
- So: is the idea just that a querying user could use HTTP/2, but internally the comms would still be HTTP/1?
Updated master comment. We have not tested it internally yet but I will gladly do so before removing `discuss`
LGTM!

Its definitely possible. I am not very familiar with the task management part of the code but after having a quick look it seems like `TaskStatus` could be changed to include location information so that when the task is done, the location information can be stored in metadata store along with the status, id and duration. 

However, again if the task logs are sent to deep storage (HDFS/S3/Azure etc) then they can be accessed from the console directly. If you must store the logs locally (not recommended for production) then one trick is to use any parallel ssh tool to `ls` for a specific task log that you are looking for in `druid.indexer.logs.directory` on all middle managers.

Thanks for the clarification. This patch looks good, but could you please test it first? Either a unit test, or integration test, or statement that you tested it manually if the other two options aren't feasible.
I'll test it in our cluster and report back. Then remove the discuss tag
LGTM!

Do you have any segments that were created by one of the buggy versions (what #3578 fixed)? If so, since the bug led to bad segments on disk, you have to reindex the bad segments or else you'll keep seeing this error even in 'good' versions of Druid.

FWIW we never released an 'official' release with the bug, but you might have got it if you built from master at some point or used the earlier 0.9.2 RCs.

"When set to `false`, disables reading from the query cache for this query. When set to `true`, Druid uses `druid.broker.cache.useCache` or `druid.broker.cache.populateCache` to determine whether or not to read from the query cache."

And, something similar for populateCache would be great too. It has the same sort of behavior.

Thanks @gianm for accepting changes.

You should be able to get the customers and the timestamps with:

```sql
select customer_id, max(__time)
from tbl
group by customer_id
order by max(__time) desc
limit 10
```

Or the equivalent topN or groupBy native query.

Then you'd want to find the records that have those `customer_id` and `__time` pairs. You could do it with a select query filtering on an OR of ANDs (each AND on a customer_id and a timestamp). But you might get more than 10 rows back if the same customer_id did more than one purchase in the same millisecond. If your app can handle that, you should be fine.

Btw, you should have been able to do that entire thing with Druid SQL, although there's a planner bug that prevents the most natural query from working: #4208, which would have been:

```sql
select * from tbl where (customer_id, __time) in (
  select customer_id, max(__time)
  from tbl
  group by customer_id
  order by max(__time) desc
  limit 10
)
```

(That might still have returned more than 10 rows if the same customer_id/__time pair occurs more than once)
Hmm, not really sure what might have caused that. Do you use the "cardinality" aggregator with any query types other than topN? If so have you noticed if they are ok or not?

@pjain1 I plan to read through this soon. Just from a really brief look though, KafkaIndexTask is 2200 lines now -- wow! It's probably worth looking at breaking this up into smaller files, maybe we could use a layer that sits between KafkaIndexTask and FiniteAppenderatorDriver. Or maybe incorporating the functionality into FiniteAppenderatorDriver, so it's no longer _finite_ but can support handing off multiple times. What do you think?

I might have more specific ideas after reading through…
The patch looks good to me. I left a trivial comment, but I'm fine with as it is.

As far as I understand, currently KafkaSupervisor calls `/stop` on tasks which fails to complete within `completionTimeout`. So this is expected behavior, irrespective of whether the segment push to HDFS completes or not, the task status would be `SUCCESS` as the task is asked to stop and not actually Killed. 

Therefore, a correct fix would be change KafkaSupervisor to actually kill the task after `completionTimeout` and that would report the task as `FAILED`. Btw https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4178 changes the behavior to kill instead of stop. Please, correct me if I am wrong.

@gianm I've had success using lookups in the past, but as I've added more to the system both in count and lookup types, I am getting `Unknown error updating configuration` errors when attempting to POST lookups to my coordinator node.

You mentioned storing lookups in S3 and then referencing these from the lookup definition. I can't seem to find any documentation for doing so? I am storing our lookups in GCS (along with our segments for deep storage, etc.) and was hoping you could help.

UPDATE: is this the  documentation I should reference? http://druid.io/docs/latest/development/extensions-core/lookups-cached-global.html
Thanks.

Actually `DriverHolder` class is kind of a layer between KafkaIndexTask and FiniteAppenderatorDriver. KafkaIndexTask does not call methods on FiniteAppenderatorDriver nor it creates instances of it directly, it uses methods on DriverHolder so this class can probably be moved to a separate file, that will be around 500-600 lines.
That'd probably help for understanding the code. I'll have a more specific opinion after reading, but it does sound like a good idea to split that out.
@gianm What would you recommened is the max size of a lookup map? My largest lookup is about 10MB.
:+1: I like the idea

@gianm you're right that this is to capture actual exception in the logs in addition to query stats in request log (after #4169 ) . I think @drcrallen was suspecting that #4169 would end up logging query stats twice in request log which shouldn't happen.
